Los Lobos had earned a reputation as one of the most intelligent and creative roots rock acts in America with the albums By the Light of the Moon and The Neighborhood, but it was with 1992's Kiko that they really demonstrated the breadth of their sonic ambitions. At its best, Kiko sounds like the musical equivalent of a Luis BuÃƒÂ±uel dream sequence, balancing beauty and menace with intelligence and a skill thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s little short of dazzling; itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a brilliant, singular achievement, and the most rewarding album in the groupÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s catalog.

Mastered from original master tapes, Mobile FidelityÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hybrid SACD version of Kiko presents the record in previously unimaginable fidelity. In particular, FroomÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s exquisite production can now be experienced in full relief, with the vintage tape-loop keyboards and spare arrangements yielding an ethereal feel, otherworldly ambience, and colorful finish that complement the ace playing. The subtleties of the richly detailed backdrops-splashed with distortion, feedback, random sound effects, sonorous horns, ominous chants, delicately plucked harps Ã¢â‚¬â€œ are greatly enhanced, turning the multifaceted Kiko into the aural equivalent of a sensational IMAX presentation.
